item.title: Mindfulness
item.description:
God's perspective is central

We view as if from the outside.

We recognize and evaluate our own thoughts and feelings

What are we thinking and feeling?
Why?

We recognize the truth of what is happening around us.

Circumstances
People

I feel very angry at Joe for ignoring me at the last meeting.


Begin your day with prayer and reading of Scripture
Prepare your heart. Invite the Holy Spirit to fill you, mindful of the fruit of the Spirit.
Take short relaxation breaks. Throughout the day, take short breaks to engage in mindful prayer exercises. Inhale grace and thanks, and breathe out stress.
Documenting/journaling. Reflect on your interactions with clients and co-workers, and write Progress Notes, Personal Journal entries, Team Agenda Notes and Blessages.
Practice Active Listening: When interacting with the girls or colleagues, practice active listening by giving your full attention to the speaker without judgment or interruption. Truly hear what they are saying and respond with empathy and compassion.
Pray for others:
Girls in the program
Co-workers
Practice Forgiveness and Letting Go: Throughout the day, practice forgiveness for yourself and others. Let go of any resentments or frustrations, allowing God's grace to flow through you and cultivate a spirit of peace and reconciliation.
End-of-Day Reflection: Before ending your day, take a few moments for reflection and gratitude. Review the events of the day with a spirit of openness and self-awareness, acknowledging both challenges and moments of growth. Offer prayers of thanks for God's presence and guidance throughout the day.

item.description:
Volunteer Position

Actively support and care for workers and volunteers.

Care Team Members must be called by God, capable of offering compassionate, thoughtful prayer, coaching and acts of kindness to Sapphire personnel. And most importantly, they must be available. Team members will check in regularly with workers, not simply wait to be contacted.

Members must have a firsthand understanding of the complex challenges of caring for children on a daily basis. They must be able to listen carefully, and provide both encouragement and exhortation as needed.

This is a matter of prioritization. Members must know that God has a special purpose for them such that they give it high priority relative to other responsibilities, including being ready to make sacrifices in their care for Sapphire workers.






Team members commit to a minimum of one year, and give notice of planned departure at least 3 months in advance.

item.title: Summary
item.description:
#search

Proposed is a new network of small boardings schools for young teens and preteens. These homes will not only provide opportunity for girls to grow and learn in safety, but will serve as touchpoints to expose many to both the needs of hurting kids but best practices in caring for them, following the example of Jesus.



Another quiet pandemic has been gripping Thailand. Between the continued downward spiral of family breakdown and the negative effects of technology/social media, children are increasingly traumatized, suffering from high anxiety, depression and dysfunctional behaviors. We see many dropping out of school (or being expelled, especially during grades 7 and 8. Many report frequent bullying.
Not only are school personnel barely trained in handling these kinds of issues, and there are no trained specialists, such as counselors or social workers.
A high percentage of kids, especially in working class environments, experience sexual exploitation at a young age. Usually the abuser is someone well known, e.g. a stepfather, uncle or neighbor.
Meanwhile, after a hiatus during the COVID-19 pandemic, the sex industry has fully rebounded. And while men's entertainment establishments are buzzing, the online platforms are growing.
The visible commercial sex industry is however only the tip of a large iceberg of exploitation, as girls are pimped to local men by older girls, young women, and in some cases, even their mothers.


The problem of sexual exploitation tends to bring girls to mind, but boys are also highly at risk, especially in the lower/working class where father absence and other instability is common.
Lack of role models
Both experience sexual abuse
Socialized into addictions: sex, substances, gaming
Social media heavily promotes narcissism.
This is not only about saving lives, but of saving society: making disciples who will teach others, that is, raising kids into leadership.
There is a the very practical issue that women need husbands. While this may sound silly to a Westerner, it is indeed a reality for lower-class Thai women.

item.title: About
item.description:
I am a creative, dot-connecting visionary. Shy extrovert, meaning I'm energized by people but naturally self-conscious. The visionary part goes with substantial ADHD, although I'm not sure about the 'H', which makes for poor management. That is, I easily think of many things to do but then forget to check my to-do list.



B.A. Psychology Wheaton College, 1979
M.Div. Trinity Ev. Divinity School, 1984
Founding member and Associate Pastor overseeing worship, music and young adult ministry at Uptown Baptist Church in Chicago, a multi-ethnic inner-city Southern Baptist congregation, 1981-1993. Interim lead pastor for 2 years, 1993-95.
Director of Cup of Cold Water Ministries (http://ccmw.org), a small independent mission-sending agency. Initiated its movement away from a narrow focus on community to development in Bolivia to an international sending scope, 1996-2000. It was during this tenure that I first visited Thailand and received the call to come.
Independent video creator/producer, 2000-2004. Produced/created videos for Christian ministries; mostly in Illinois but also overseas. During this period also worked attempting to do house-style church geared at low-income residents in Aurora, Illinois. It was slow going and difficult, but it began some of the paradigm shifts that are covered in this proposal.
Servantworks Thailand coordinator, 2004-present.


Grew up in a tiny country church in Illinois, within a very evangelical tradition of Lutheranism, descended from Norwegian revivalist Hans Neilson Hauge.
Trusted Jesus at a young age; became passionate for the Great Commission since childhood; grew up frustrated with the parish style of the Lutheran church that included many nominal members.
Got exposed to Southern Baptist tradition on annual visits to Dallas to visit my mother's family. Loved the emphasis on the Gospel and the weekly altar call.
Active in direct evangelism to strangers since high school, both on the street and door-to-door. Door-to-door was also a significant part of our work in Chicago.
Connected with Uptown Baptist Church in 1977 while a student at Wheaton. It was then a small storefront in a rough, neighborhood that was also an immigrant port of entry.
Made a commitment as a young adult to live modestly in order to devote the most possible resources to reaching others; also to live in places of need. Judy also shared this commitment. We were the first wedding held at UBC.
Worked in a facility caring for chronic mentally ill, also led Bible study along with Judy. Attended TEDS by commute while living in Chicago; graduated and was ordained at UBC in 1984.

item.title: Summary
item.description:
Thai people are ready for Jesus
We regularly see people drawn to Jesus when they have opportunity to understand
We moved here in 2004 with the expectation that God had something big planned. Like prophetic foreshortening we expected quicker timing, but ultimately we see no reason to believe differently.


Began 200 years ago.
Proselytization illegal until 1900, so nineteenth century missionaries focused on non-citizens: ethnic Chinese and hill tribe groups. But during the 1900's little happened to reach southern, central and northeast Thais.
Campus Crusade reported 1 million professions of faith in response to the Jesus Movie campaign in the 1980's. A friend of mine was on one of the teams.
In 2004, the Arthur S. DeMoss Foundation distributed over two million copies of their Power for Living booklet in response to TV ads.

2010_0512_Reaching_Thailand_in_this_Generation.pdf (worldevangelicals.org)

item.title: Introduction
item.description:
Many more ministries than 20 years ago
Churches have multiplied; Christians doubled from 0.5 to 1%
More people doing ministry who have been healed from broken backgrounds


Sex industry keeps growing, perhaps even more rapidly since COVID. We're not keeping up.
Increasing use of social media/web sites of women selling themselves
Brokenness keeps growing
Drugs are now everywhere. Yaba is so cheap.
More and more broken people having children.
Possibility that prostitution will be legalized.
The needs and risk factors of exploited or at-risk persons are complex
